the burial place of their kings are in
the land of the gerai
which is the end of the navigation of
the baristanis
there whenever their king has died the
scythians dig a great
four-cornered pit in the ground when
this is ready they take up the dead man
his body enclosed in wax his belly cut
open and cleansed and filled with cut
marsh plants and frankincense and
parsley and aniseed and sewn up again
then having laid the dead in the tomb on
a couch they plant spears all round the
body
and lay across them wooden planks which
they then
roof over with hides in the open space
which is left in the tomb they bury
after strangling
one of the king's concubines his cup
bearer his cook his groom his squire
and his messenger besides horse and
first fruits of all else
and golden cups
after the burial the scythians cleanse
themself as i will show
they anoint and wash their heads as for
their bodies they set up
three poles leaning together to a point
and cover these over with woolen rugs
then in the place so enclosed the best
of their power
they make a pit in the center beneath
the poles
and the rugs and throw red hot stones
into it
they have hemp growing in their country
very like flax
this grows both of itself and also by
their sowing and of it the thracians
even make garments which are very like
linen
the scythians then take the seed of this
hemp and creeping under the rugs they

and being so thrown its smolders and

that no greek vapor bath could surpass

the scythians howl in joy for the vapor
bath
this serves them instead of bathing for
scarce ever do they wash their bodies
with water
but their women grind with a rough stone
cypress and cedar and frankincense wood
pouring water also there on and with the
thick stuff so ground they anoint all
their bodies and faces
whereby not only does a fragrant scent
abide upon them
but when on the second day they take off
their ointment their skin becomes clean
and shining

the farming scythians inhabit a land
stretching eastward a three days journey
to a river called panticarpus and
northwood as far as an 11 days voyage
of the baristanese and north of these
the land is uninhabited for a long way
after which desert is the country of the
man-eaters
who are a nation by themselves and by no
means scythian
and beyond them is true desert wherein
no nation of man dwells as far as we
know
but to the east of these farming
scythians cross the river panticarpus
and you are in the land of nomads
scythians who sow nothing
nor plow and all these lands except the
woodlands are bare of trees
these nomads inhabit to the eastward a
country that stretches 14 days journey
to the river guerras across the guerras
there are lands called
royal where are the best and most in

who deem all other syrians their slaves
their territory stretches
